SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A TREAT OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON ANSWERING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering them all. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Plat: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Expect?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board
University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Sask.

A NOTE OF APPRECIATION TO THE PERSONS WHO ANSWER THIS QUESTIONNAIRE.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has had enough experience on pioneer life to make his answers valuable. Some of the questions here will not apply to you, but others may be answered by anyone who has personal experience or the pioneer life. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you did not or you may use "I was a small child")

42. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The first thing I notice was the railroad coming through.

The next big change was when the wheat prices started going up.

And the third thing was when we had to cut our expenses because of the depression.

The fourth thing was when we had to work for the government.

And the fifth thing was when we had to move to town.

When they go and come back they still send us help wages.

And the last thing was when they end the supply.
